metadata.title: Earnings Multiple Valuation Calculator (Advanced)
metadata.description: Multi-method valuation tool to estimate Equity or Enterprise value using P/E (earnings multiple), EV/EBITDA, and Revenue multiple approaches. Includes controls for normalization, net debt adjustments, control premiums, minority discounts, and per-share calculations.

equity_pe.label: Equity value using P/E (Price-to-Earnings)
equity_pe.description: Estimates equity value directly by applying a P/E multiple to normalized earnings, then applies control premium and minority discount adjustments and divides by shares outstanding for per-share value.

enterprise_ebitda.label: Enterprise Value using EV/EBITDA
enterprise_ebitda.description: Estimates enterprise value by multiplying normalized EBITDA by an EV/EBITDA multiple, then reconciles to equity value by subtracting net debt and minority interest, and adding cash.

revenue_multiple.label: Enterprise Value using Revenue Multiple
revenue_multiple.description: Estimates enterprise value by applying a revenue multiple to normalized revenue, then reconciles to equity value by subtracting net debt and minority interest, and adding cash.

per_share_revenue.label: Estimated Price per Share (from Revenue EV)

outputs.label: Estimated Price per Share (from Revenue EV)

fields.label: Normalized Earnings (Net Income or Adjusted EPS × shares)
Cash and equivalents to add back
Minority interest / non-controlling interest to subtract
Control premium (%) to apply to buyer price

introduction: This multi-method valuation calculator estimates company value using earnings multiples: P/E (equity multiple), EV/EBITDA, and revenue multiples. It supports normalized income inputs, adjustments for net debt, cash, minority interests, control premiums, and per-share results to assist transaction modelling and sanity checks.

Use this tool as a rapid approximation and calibration aid. It is not a substitute for a full valuation report prepared by a qualified appraiser or financial advisor that includes due diligence, forecast modelling, and careful reconciliation of accounting adjustments.
methodology: The calculator applies widely used market multiple techniques: multiply an earnings metric by an appropriate multiple, then reconcile enterprise-to-equity values by adding cash and subtracting net debt and minority interests. P/E is applied directly to equity earnings, while EV multiples are applied to enterprise metrics and converted to equity value.

Inputs should be normalized (one-off items removed, owner compensation adjusted, non-operating gains/losses excluded). Choose industry averages only after confirming comparability in business model, growth, margin profile, capital intensity, and size.
how_is_calculated: P/E (Equity) approach: Equity value = Normalized Earnings × Selected P/E multiple; apply control premium and minority discount as percentages; Price per share = Equity value ÷ Shares outstanding.

EV/EBITDA approach: Enterprise value = Normalized EBITDA × Selected EV/EBITDA multiple; Equity value = Enterprise value − Net Debt + Cash − Minority Interest; Price per share = Equity value ÷ Shares outstanding.
Revenue multiple approach: Enterprise value = Normalized Revenue × Selected Revenue multiple; Equity value reconciled like EV/EBITDA approach.
examples: If normalized earnings are 200,000 and selected P/E is 8, estimated equity value = 200,000 × 8 = 1,600,000. With 100,000 shares outstanding, price per share = 16.00.
If normalized EBITDA is 300,000 and EV/EBITDA median is 6, enterprise value = 1,800,000. If net debt = 200,000 and cash = 50,000, equity value = 1,800,000 − 200,000 + 50,000 = 1,650,000.

faqs.question: How should I choose the multiple?
faqs.answer: Select a multiple from comparable public companies or recent transactions that match size, growth, margin, and business model. Industry averages are a starting point; adjust using company-specific risk, growth outlook, and profitability. For regulatory or audit work, document sources and justification for the chosen multiple.

faqs.question: What are common adjustments to earnings before applying a multiple?
faqs.answer: Remove non-recurring gains/losses, normalize owner compensation, adjust for related-party transactions, and restate accounting treatments where comparables use different policies. Use consistent recurring metrics for comparability.

faqs.question: Can this calculator be used for audited or regulatory valuations?
faqs.answer: This tool produces indicative results. For audited or regulatory valuations, retain a licensed valuation professional. Ensure work follows applicable standards (e.g., IFRS/US GAAP for financials) and document methodology, assumptions, and sensitivity analyses.

faqs.question: How accurate are these estimates?
faqs.answer: Accuracy depends on input quality and choice of multiples. These methods are sensitive to normalization choices and multiples. Use sensitivity testing and scenario analysis; disclose uncertainty and the range of plausible values.

faqs.question: How should I handle control premiums and minority discounts?
faqs.answer: Control premiums and minority discounts reflect market practice and transaction evidence. Apply them as percentages to reflect the difference between controlling interest and a minority stake. Document market sources and rationale.

glossary.definition: Earnings adjusted to remove one-off items, owner-specific compensation distortions, and non-operating items so recurring operating profitability is represented.
Total firm value equal to market capitalization plus net debt (debt minus cash) and minority interests; represents value attributable to all capital providers.
Percentage increase applied to reflect the additional price a buyer might pay to acquire a controlling interest in a company.
Percentage reduction applied to reflect liquidity or governance disadvantages of holding a minority interest versus a controlling stake.
Ratio (e.g., P/E, EV/EBITDA, EV/Revenue) used to convert a financial metric into an implied valuation based on market comparables or transaction evidence.

summary: This tool provides scenario-based, multi-method valuation estimates. It is intended for quick analysis, calibration, and sensitivity exploration; it is not a substitute for formal valuation engagement.

For regulated, audited, or transaction-grade valuations, work with licensed professionals and retain source documentation, follow applicable accounting rules, and perform sensitivity and scenario analysis.
